the winter time he usually hid in caves. He imme- diately disclosed the desired road, and for about two hundred miles, turning aside neither to the left nor to the right, showed a passable way. For he went just far enough ahead of them so that his fresh track broke out a path. So, leading through the desert wilderness‚ the beast did not forsake the men who were bringing relies to the needy, but with the utmost possible friendliness conducted them as far as human habita— tions. Then‚ having fulfilled his duty, he turned aside and departed: showing by the great service of his guidance what men ought to do for men, and how much love they ought to display, since here a savage beast showed the road to the despairing.

When the arrivals were announced to the servant of God, he said, “ Blessed be the name of the Lord 1 Let them enter, to whom a bear hath opened a way for their coming.'' When they heard this they marvelled with exceeding great amazement that the man of God should tell that which had happened in his absence.

CHAPTER XXX
